overview_of_class:
COURSE DESCRIPTION / Relationship between social, political, and economic problems in engineering; contracts; competitive bidding; the engineer's role in management; liability; insurance; lawsuits; arbitration; legal implications of environmental laws; professional societies; ethics.

GOALS / To familiarize students with legal processes and legal and administrative relationships that will be encountered in the current practice of engineering and the steps that should be taken to minimize or avoid disputes.
name: Engineering Law
title: MEAS CIV_ENV 302-0-20 Engineering Law

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
COURSE DESCRIPTION / Relationship between social, political, and economic problems in engineering; contracts; competitive bidding; the engineer's role in management; liability; insurance; lawsuits; arbitration; legal implications of environmental laws; professional societies; ethics.

GOALS / To familiarize students with legal processes and legal and administrative relationships that will be encountered in the current practice of engineering and the steps that should be taken to minimize or avoid disputes.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
The objectives of this course are:
(1) to instill a basic understanding and appreciation for a wide variety of legal principles,
(2) to familiarize students with legal processes and legal and administrative relationships that will likely be encountered in the current practice of engineering,
(3) to foster a disciplined approach whereby both sides of an issue are carefully analyzed, and
(4) to impart a perception of situations in which it is advisable to elicit the expertise of an attorney.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Instruction by practicing attorneys with expertise in specific topics.

descriptions.name: Class Notes
descriptions.value: Course is taught by Prof. Raymond J. Krizek, Howard B. Rockman and Prof. Patrick E. Croke
